description.narrative:
Sveriges Kommuner och Landsting (SKL, eller SALAR på engelska) har sökt stöd om totalt 24 790 000 SEK för programmet "SKL: Tunisia Local Governance Project 2015-2017" under 24 månader under perioden 2015-2017.
Insatsen är en fortsättning av ett drygt 1-årigt pilotprojekt som SKL implementerade i Tunisien 2013-2014.
Insatsen syftar till att stärka de tunisiska kommunerna samt att lärdomar från den tunisiska-, och andra länders decentraliseringserfarenheter, används av decentraliseringsreformförespråkare i andra länder i Mena-regionen.
En central del av projektet handlar om att hjälpa till att stärka kapacitet och legitimitet av den tunisiska motsvarigheten till SKL, Fédération Nationale des Villes Tunisiennes (FNVT) så att FNVT effektivt kan företräda sina medlemmar kommunerna och spela en mer självständig roll gentemot centralregeringen och komma med relevanta inspel och förslag i den tunisiska decentraliseringsprocessen.
Det finns även en regional komponent av insatsen som skall startas igång som syftar till att dela goda erfarenheter och skapa nätverk och kontakter mellan decentraliseringsförespråkare i Mena-regionen.
Den totala budgeten för insatsen är 24 790 000 SEK och Sida finansierar hela denna summan. Ingen del av budgeten kommer att vidareförmedlas däremot kommer större delen av budgeten att gå vidare till SKL-International som har ett ramavtal med SKL vad gäller implementering av internationella insatser. SKL-International kommer att sköta implementeringen i fält av insatsen.

The Swedish Association of Local Authorities and Regions (SALAR) has sought support for a total of 24,790,000 SEK for the program "SKL: Tunisia Local Governance Project 2015-2017" during 4 months during the period 2015-2017.
The initiative is a continuation of a one-year pilot project that SALAR implemented in Tunisia 2013-2014.
The initiative aims to strengthen the Tunisian local government and that lessons from Tunisian and other countries' decentralisation experiences are considered by reform advocates in MENA transition countries.
A central part of the project is to help strengthen the capacity and legitimacy of the Tunisian equivalent of SALAR, the Fédération Nationale des Villes Tunisiennes (FNVT) so that FNVT can effectively represent its members, the local authorities and play a more independent role vis-à-vis the central government and come up with relevant input and suggestions in the Tunisian decentralization process.
There is also a regional component of the initiative that aims to share good experiences and establish networks and contacts between decentralization advocates in the MENA region.
The total budget for the operation is 24,790,000 SEK and Sida funds this entire sum. No part of the budget will be subgranted however the larger part of the budget will go to SKL International, which has a framework agreement with SALAR and which will be the entity that will manage implementation in the field of the operation.

The overall impact goal for the project is that "Tunisian local government is strengthened and lessons learned from Tunisian and other countries' decentralisation experiences are considered by reform advocates in the Mena transition countries"

sector.narrative: Decentralisation and support to subnational government

description.narrative: According to the reporting the project contributed to strengthening Tunisian Local Government by achieving three key outcomes: 1. Adoption and application of the Code des Collectivités Locales (CCL) Through its support to the Tunisian parliament in drafting the CCL, the project contributed to creating the legal provisions for Local Governments to become important actors in Tunisia's decentralised political system. The CCL is the basis for all future decentralisation in Tunisia and stipulates the prerogatives of Local Governments in Tunisia’s future three-tier system. The new law stipulates all prerogatives of local authorities in Tunisia: its functions, its obligations, its financial system, matters of property, intergovernmental relations and internal management. It is applicable to all three levels of Local Government: municipalities, regions and districts. The project did so by building the capacities of the COAAFA, supporting the referral process (not least via the Forum of Financial Managers) and contributing to the formulation of specific decrees, laws and manuals that are indispensable for the application of the CCL. 2. Integration of municipalities into law-making process The project contributed to the above outcome through the establishment of the Forum of Financial Managers (a network of financial managers from the municipalities’ administration within FNVT, Fédération National des Ville Tunisiennes) The forum was invited in its capacity as representation of FNVT and thereby its members, the municipalities. This was the first time in Tunisian law-making, that municipalities were formally involved in the legislative process. By supporting IPAPD, national dialogue improved and the political debate at the COAAFA opened up for referrals during which non-state actors were allowed to present their recommendations on the CCL.Through the project, the Forum developed 36 recommendations on the CCL of which 19 were considered by the COAAFA. They were included into a new draft of the CCL and later adopted by the Tunisian National Assembly. Thereby municipalities left their mark on the CCL which is rooted in their understanding of the challenges that they identified with regard to local financial management. 3. Effective project implementation and coordination of existing services FNVT has with support of the project increased its professionalism. FNVT’s Executive Director has gained control over the management of the organisation and its external presentation. FNVT is also more professionally represented towards the Government and FNVT’s management has close relationships and is included in regular exchange with relevant ministries and other partners.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
